entry.content:
Feb 2020

Â Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Morbi convallis nunc eget magna pulvinar gravida. Proin at nibh vitae justo bibendum accumsan sed at quam. Donec arcu ex, suscipit et est sit amet, pulvinar consequat elit. Vestibulum maximus porttitor ornare. In ullamcorper orci sem, vel posuere velit maximus et. Ut ac dapibus massa, ac consectetur enim. Orci varius natoque penatibus et magnis dis parturient montes, nascetur ridiculus mus. Vestibulum vel venenatis nunc. Fusce hendrerit et arcu ut efficitur. Donec vestibulum, arcu in fermentum venenatis, dui risus tristique nunc, ut vestibulum tellus orci sit amet ex. Suspendisse vulputate massa at ligula tincidunt, nec ultricies tellus malesuada. Aliquam blandit malesuada dui ac mattis. Morbi pretium, leo sed sodales mollis, nulla turpis iaculis quam, eget sodales est turpis eleifend nisl. Nulla eu suscipit tellus.

Donec dui tortor, consectetur cursus neque vitae, mollis tristique libero. Sed eget mattis nunc. Quisque venenatis, ante pellentesque facilisis mollis, diam sapien porttitor quam, sed facilisis nunc enim tincidunt neque. Aenean rhoncus mauris tellus, eget hendrerit velit suscipit at. Duis tincidunt mollis urna, sed bibendum metus tempor non. Phasellus ut posuere dolor. Sed gravida placerat augue sit amet tincidunt. Sed lacinia enim eu sapien tempor ultricies. Sed dapibus tristique porttitor. Integer nibh erat, placerat nec magna nec, placerat tincidunt justo. Nulla scelerisque nisl et mauris lacinia congue. Mauris posuere imperdiet consequat. Donec mattis lorem sed nisl vestibulum faucibus. Aenean congue dapibus volutpat. Etiam quis pharetra dui. Aenean non est elementum, ultricies sapien egestas, bibendum ipsum.Â

Website Team

Â 

Education & Science Promotion

iGEM

Since 2012, D. Dupuy supervises Bordeaux iGEM team to encourage students to focus on Synthetic biology. Every year, 20-25 students from Universities and Bordeaux engineering school, form a team and develop a project all year long which is then brought to a successful conclusion within the framework of voluntary internships during summer. Work results are then present at the occasion of a big conference in Boston that met ~ 400 teams coming from all over the world. (www.igem.org)

Â 

Former et enseigner

La recherche et l'enseignement vont de pair Ã  l'IECB. Les chercheurs de l'IECB forment en permanence plus de quarante Ã©tudiants des Ã©coles doctorales enÂ sciences chimiquesÂ etÂ sciences de la vieÂ de l'UniversitÃ© de Bordeaux. L'IECB accueille rÃ©guliÃ¨rement ces Ã©tudiants pour des cours et des ateliers pratiques.

Certains chercheurs de l'IECB produisent des ressources pÃ©dagogiques internationales (manuels, ressources multimÃ©dia en ligne, voir par exemple le siteÂ Cell biology promotion).

Â 

Valoriser les jeunes chercheurs

Les jeunes chercheurs (masters, doctorants et post-doctorants) reprÃ©sentent plus de la moitiÃ© de l'effectif de l'IECB. Cette communautÃ© dynamique et internationale est Ã  l'initiative d'un Ã©vÃ¨nement destinÃ© aux jeunes chercheurs en chimie, biologie et physique: lesÂ JournÃ©es Jeunes Chercheurs de l'IECB. Cet Ã©vÃ¨nement, organisÃ© par et pour les jeunes chercheurs, vise Ã  promouvoir les interactions interdisciplinaires et Ã  informer les doctorants des diffÃ©rentes carriÃ¨res envisageables aprÃ¨s la thÃ¨se.

Â 

Promouvoir la science

Les chercheurs de l'IECB (titulaires, post-doctorants et Ã©tudiants) contribuent Ã  la promotion de science et Ã  la diffusion du savoir scientifique au sein de la sociÃ©tÃ©. Il discutent des problÃ¨mes scientifiques liÃ©s Ã  la santÃ© avec les collÃ©giens et lycÃ©ens d'Aquitaine lors des rencontresÂ Aquitaine en dÃ©bats. Ils contribuent aux actions organisÃ©es par â€œCap Sciencesâ€, le centre de culture scientifique technique & industrielle d'Aquitaine, et ouvrent chaque annÃ©e leurs laboratoires aux lycÃ©ens et collÃ©giens d'Aquitaine pour des visites, des ateliers et des confÃ©rences Ã  l'occasion de laÃ‚Ã‚Ã‚Â FÃªte de la Science.

entry.title: Birgit Habenstein recipient of the CNRS Momentum
entry.summary:
Birgit Habenstein, CNRS researcher at the IECB in the team Â«Ã‚Ã‚ NMR of Molecular Assemblies" has been awarded the CNRS-Momentum funding for her project "Molecular Mechanisms of the force generation during bacterial division at the atomic levelÂ». She will use NMR spectroscopy to study processes linked to bacterial division at an atomic resolution.


CNRS-Momentum is a recent national program to provide the financial basis for young researchers to conduct their independent and ambitious projects. From 383 eligible projects, Birgit's project has been selected as one of the 20 projects to benefit from the 3-year funding.
entry.content:
Birgit Habenstein, CNRS researcher at the IECB in the team Â«Ã‚Ã‚ NMR of Molecular Assemblies" has been awarded the CNRS-Momentum funding for her project "Molecular Mechanisms of the force generation during bacterial division at the atomic levelÂ». She will use NMR spectroscopy to study processes linked to bacterial division at an atomic resolution.


CNRS-Momentum is a recent national program to provide the financial basis for young researchers to conduct their independent and ambitious projects. From 383 eligible projects, Birgit's project has been selected as one of the 20 projects to benefit from the 3-year funding.

Link > CNRS Momentum 2018

entry.title: Control and dynamics of cell division
entry.summary:
Summary

The mechanisms that safeguard cells against aneuploidy are of great interest as aneuploidy contributes to tumorigenesis. Using live imaging approaches, we have identified two novel mechanisms that permit the accurate transmission of chromosomes during cell division. The first mechanism involves the faithful segregation of damaged chromosomes. Our studies reveal that chromosome fragments segregate properly to opposite poles. This poleward motion is mediated through DNA tethers that connect the chromosome fragments. The second mechanism involves the coordination of chromosome segregation with cell cleavage. We found that cells can adapt to a four-fold increase in chromatid length by elongating transiently during anaphase. This mechanism ensures the clearance of chromatids from the cleavage plane at the appropriate time during cytokinesis, thus preserving genome integrity.

Activity report

Mitosis is the final stage of the cell cycle where a copy of the duplicated genome condensed into chromosomes is transmitted to each daughter cell. Failure to do so produces daughter cells with an inappropriate genome content, also called aneuploidy. The mechanisms that safeguard cells against aneuploidy are of great interest as aneuploidy contributes to tumorigenesis. Our group has identified two novel mechanisms that permit the accurate transmission of chromosomes during cell division. The first mechanism involves the faithful segregation of damaged chromosomes. The second mechanism coordinates chromosome segregation with cell cleavage.

Mechanism that permits faithful transmission of broken chromosomes

Correct transmission of the genetic material requires proper chromosome attachment to spindle microtubules. The centromere of the chromosome serves as an assembly site for a multi-protein structure called the kinetochore, the functional unit that binds the microtubules. The centromere is, thus, essential for proper chromosome segregation. However, we have recently identified a mechanism by which fragments of broken chromosomes lacking centromeres segregate properly. This is achieved through a novel chromatin conformation that tethers the acentric chromosome fragments to their centric partners. The efficient segregation of the broken chromosome fragments depends on the spindle assembly checkpoint component BubR1. BubR1 localizes on the kinetochore until anaphase onset and accumulates on the â€œtetherâ€, the chromatin structure that attaches the chromosome fragments, throughout mitosis. To determine how BubR1 recruitment to the â€œtetherâ€ is regulated, we monitored dividing cells expressing BubR1 constructs lacking specific domains. We found that the conserved Bub3-Binding Domain and more specifically the Glutamate 481 (E481) are required for BubR1 localization on the tether. Since E481 is essential for BubR1 interaction with Bub3 and its localization on the kinetochore, we investigated whether Bub3 localizes to the tether and more generally whether the â€œtetherâ€ is an assembly site for other kinetochore proteins (Figure 1). We analysed the localization of five core kinetochore proteins and did not detect any signal on the â€œtetherâ€. In contrast, Bub3 accumulated on the â€œtetherâ€ throughout mitosis. Bub3 and BubR1 were inter-dependent for their localization on the kinetochore and tether. In addition, we found that Cdc20, a key subunit of the APC/C, was recruited on the â€œtetherâ€ in a BubR1 and Bub3 dependent manner throughout mitosis (Figure 1). The expression of a BubR1 mutant lacking the KEN box, a motif required for Cdc20 binding to BubR1, exhibited severe defects in broken chromosome segregation and was associated with a lack of Cdc20 localization on the tether. To test if BubR1 inhibited locally the APC/C on the â€œtetherâ€, we constructed a synthetic APC/C substrate. To do so, we fused the N terminal sequence of Cyclin B to GFP::Bub3 (DB-Bub3) and monitored its dynamics in the presence of broken chromosomes. We found that DB-Bub3 persisted on the â€œtetherâ€ during early anaphase in a BubR1 KEN box dependent manner. All together these results favour a model in which Bub3 recruits BubR1 on broken chromosomes, which, in turn, inhibits the APC/C locally by sequestering Cdc20 throughout mitosis. This local APC/C inhibition during anaphase preserves key components important for maintaining the broken fragments tethered.

Chromosome segregation must be coordinated with cell division to ensure proper transmission of the genetic material into daughter cells. Our group identified a novel mechanism by which Drosophila neuronal stem cells coordinate chromosome segregation with cell division. Cells adapt to the presence of chromatid arms at the cleavage site by transiently, but dramatically, elongating during anaphase, thus increasing the rate at which the long chromatids clear the cleavage plane. This adaptive elongation depends on myosin activity and the Rho Guanine-nucleotide exchange factor, Pebble. To understand how the cell deforms when chromatids are present at the cleavage plane, we studied the dynamics of myosin during cytokinesis in cells with or without long chromosomes. Surprisingly, halfway through cytokinesis, myosin undergoes flux from the cytokinetic ring and invades the entire cortex. In control cells, myosin efflux is transient, as myosin dissociates from the cortex upon reformation of the nuclear envelope. However, cells with long chromatids exhibit an extended period of myosin efflux associated with a delay in nuclear envelope formation (NEF). During this prolonged myosin efflux, cortical myosin forms extra rings that deform the nascent daughter cells, permitting the clearance of chromatids from the cleavage plane. We have previously shown that adaptive cell elongation depends on Pebble. Consistently myosin does not undergo efflux in pebble mutant cells with or without long chromatids. Since Pebble accumulates in the nucleus at telophase at the time myosin dissociates from the cortex, we hypothesized that the translocation of Pebble into the nucleus induces myosin dissociation from the cortex via the inactivation of RhoA. Consistently, the expression of a pebble mutant lacking a nuclear location signal induces prolonged myosin efflux associated with cell elongation and extensive blebbing, even in the absence of long chromatid arms at the cleavage site. We propose that the coordination between chromatid segregation, myosin efflux and NEF allows adaptive cell elongation to clear chromatid arms from the cleavage plane before the completion of cytokinesis.Â 

Selected publications
entry.content:
Summary

The mechanisms that safeguard cells against aneuploidy are of great interest as aneuploidy contributes to tumorigenesis. Using live imaging approaches, we have identified two novel mechanisms that permit the accurate transmission of chromosomes during cell division. The first mechanism involves the faithful segregation of damaged chromosomes. Our studies reveal that chromosome fragments segregate properly to opposite poles. This poleward motion is mediated through DNA tethers that connect the chromosome fragments. The second mechanism involves the coordination of chromosome segregation with cell cleavage. We found that cells can adapt to a four-fold increase in chromatid length by elongating transiently during anaphase. This mechanism ensures the clearance of chromatids from the cleavage plane at the appropriate time during cytokinesis, thus preserving genome integrity.

Activity report

Mitosis is the final stage of the cell cycle where a copy of the duplicated genome condensed into chromosomes is transmitted to each daughter cell. Failure to do so produces daughter cells with an inappropriate genome content, also called aneuploidy. The mechanisms that safeguard cells against aneuploidy are of great interest as aneuploidy contributes to tumorigenesis. This local APC/C inhibition during anaphase preserves key components important for maintaining the broken fragments tethered.

Our group identified a novel mechanism by which Drosophila neuronal stem cells coordinate chromosome segregation with cell division. Cells adapt to the presence of chromatid arms at the cleavage site by transiently, but dramatically, elongating during anaphase, thus increasing the rate at which the long chromatids clear the cleavage plane. This adaptive elongation depends on myosin activity and the Rho Guanine-nucleotide exchange factor, Pebble. To understand how the cell deforms when chromatids are present at the cleavage plane, we studied the dynamics of myosin during cytokinesis in cells with or without long chromosomes. Surprisingly, halfway through cytokinesis, myosin undergoes flux from the cytokinetic ring and invades the entire cortex. In control cells, myosin efflux is transient, as myosin dissociates from the cortex upon reformation of the nuclear envelope. During this prolonged myosin efflux, cortical myosin forms extra rings that deform the nascent daughter cells, permitting the clearance of chromatids from the cleavage plane. We have previously shown that adaptive cell elongation depends on Pebble. Consistently myosin does not undergo efflux in pebble mutant cells with or without long chromatids. Since Pebble accumulates in the nucleus at telophase at the time myosin dissociates from the cortex, we hypothesized that the translocation of Pebble into the nucleus induces myosin dissociation from the cortex via the inactivation of RhoA. Consistently, the expression of a pebble mutant lacking a nuclear location signal induces prolonged myosin efflux associated with cell elongation and extensive blebbing, even in the absence of long chromatid arms at the cleavage site. We propose that the coordination between chromatid segregation, myosin efflux and NEF allows adaptive cell elongation to clear chromatid arms from the cleavage plane before the completion of cytokinesis.Â 

Selected publications

J Cell Biol. 211(3):517-32. * denotes equal contributionÂ 
  • Jose M, Tollis S, Nair D, Mitteau R, Velours C, Massoni-Laporte A, Royou A, Sibarita JB, McCusker D (2015) A quantitative imaging-based screen reveals the exocyst as a network hub connecting endocytosis and exocytosis. Mol. Biol. Cell. 26(13):2519-34Â 
  • Kotadia, S*, Montembault, E*, Sullivan, W and Royou A (2012) Cell elongation is an adaptive response for clearing long chromatid arms from the cleavage plane. J Cell Biol. 199(5):745-53. * denotes equal contribution, # denotes corresponding authorÂ

  • Royou, A., Gagou, M., Karess, R., D., Sullivan, W. (2010) BubR1 and Polo-coated DNA tethers facilitate the segregation of acentric chromatids. Cell 140(2) : 235-45.Â 
  • Royou, A., McCusker, D., Kellogg, D., Sullivan, W. (2008) Grapes(Chk1) prevents nuclear Cdk1 activation by delaying Cyclin B nuclear accumulation. J. Cell Biol. 183(1):63-75
    Riggs, B., Fasulo, B., Royou, A., Mische, S., Cao, J., Hays, TS., Sullivan, W. (2007) The concentration of Nuf, a Rab11 effector, at the microtubule-organizing center is cell cycle regulated, dynein-dependent, and coincides with furrow formation. Mol. Biol. Cell. 18(9) : 3313-22Â 
  • Chodagam, S., Royou, A., Whitfield, W., Karess, R., Raff, JW. (2005) The centrosomal protein CP190 regulates myosin function during early Drosophila development. Curr. Biol. 15 (14) : 1308-13Â

  • Royou, A., Sullivan, W., Karess, R. (2002) Cortical recruitment of non muscle myosin II in early syncytial Drosophila embryos: its role in nuclear axial expansion and its regulation by Cdc2 activity. J. Cell. Biol. 158(1):127-37

entry.title: IECB Logo Graphic Kit 2020
entry.summary:
IECB Logo Evolution 2020

Logo comment

The square of the logo and the typography of the acronym are interwoven and merge into a square shape.

The initial colour strips are assiociated to create a notion of movement. The cutting of some strips evokes a DNA sequencing of the genome in relation to the world of science and the infinitely small.

The font typeface chosen is Space Mono Regular to evoke the world of high technology using binary digital hardware.

Please respect the Logo minimal space secure. Distance = 1xE between the anothers elements.

Â 

IECB Logo XL

Download the Logo :

  • For Web Pixels > JPGÂ 
  • For Print Vector > SVG
  • Fonts Space Mono > TTF
